Ryan Hannam

Researcher - Data Scientist - Tech Nerd

About


After recently receiving my PhD in applied mathematics, I am looking for exciting new opportunities.

I am interested in complex systems - that is how the interactions between many individual entities can result in emergent behaviour that is more than simply the sum of the individual parts. Complex systems can be found in physics, biology, ecology, economics and finance, sociology and more.

The focus of my PhD was to improve the understanding of how the different cell types of an organism emerge from the underlying molecular biology, using statistical physics techniques. This involved creating mathematical models which I then tested against simulations and experimental data. During my PhD I gained skills in Boolean, gene regulatory and neural networks, stochastic simulation methods, data analysis and visualisation.

As a former member of the Disordered Systems group and CANES, I am also interested in machine learning, stochastic processes and network science. Beyond scientific research, I am also passionate about gastronomy, sports & fitness, and I have a keen interest in consumer electronics & mobile computing. If you would like to find out more about myself or my work feel free to drop me an email.

Publications

Percolation in bipartite Boolean networks and its role in sustaining life,
J. Phys. A: Math & Theor. 52 334002 (2019),
R. Hannam, R Kühn and A. Annibale.
This article was published as part of the "Disordered serendipity: a glassy path to discovery" special issue.

High gene dosage changes transcriptional regulation of genetic structures and contributes to diversity and heterogeneity, (2018)
D. Lui, R. Hannam and L. Albergante.
Preprint versions: bioRxiv.org


Cell reprogramming modelled as transitions in a hierarchy of cell cycles,
J. Phys. A: Math & Theor. 50 425601 (2017),
R. Hannam, A. Annibale, and R Kühn.
This article was also selected for the journal's "Highlights of 2017" special issue.
Preprint versions: arXiv.org, bioRxiv.org
